content:
1.) Females homozygous for BicaudalD produce embryos
which lack anterior head and thoracic structures,
forming instead two posterior abdomens in mirror image
symmetry. At gastrulation, posterior midgut
invaginations are observed at the anterior and posterior
ends of the egg. At room temperature the penetrance of
the phenotype is somewhat variable. Many embryos show
no polarity reversals and only partial reductions in
anterior structures.
.2.) Females homozygous for tudor produce embryos which
do not make germline precursors ("pole cells) and show
pattern deletions in their abdominal region.
Development at the anterior end of the egg in normal.
3.) Females homozygous for concertina produce embryos
which do not form a posterior midgut. Other
gastrulation movements are initiated normally, but the
embryo is soon thrown into multiple folds It is not
known whether the pole cells which are formed normally
make it into the interior of the embryo in the absence
of a posterior midgut invaginations
To study the effect of early zygotically active genes on the
expression of -galactosidase in these transformants, we
will use mutations in two segemntation genes and one gene
controlling morphogenetic movements at gastrulation.
1.) In embryos homozygous for the "gap" mutation
Kruppel, pattern elements in the thorax and anterior
abdomen are deleted and replaced by a mirror image
duplication somewhat similar to that observed in embryos
from Bicaudal mothers.
2.)In embryos homozygous for the "pair-rule" mutation
hairy, pattern elements in alternate segments are
deleted. The deletion consists of the posterior
portions of the odd-numbered segments and the anterior
regions of the even numbered segments.
3.) In embryos homozygous for folded gastrulation,
segmentation is normal but the animal fails to form a
posterior midgut at gastrulation. The appearance of
embryos at gastrulation is identical to that of embryos
from concertina mothers
We will discuss the results of these experiments as a group.
Most likely you will not able to stain embryos from all the
crosses listed below, but you should try to get several done.
For the crosses that you do, you should also some embryos
which have been allowed to develop for 24 hours in Hoyers
Mountant to determine the cuticle phenotypes.
